reviewText:
Albino Lullaby has a very unique atmosphere, with creepy and cool enemy designs
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6pO5zbuYnHg
There isn't much in terms of gameplay, but that's not exactly a bad thing.
The game focuses on exploration, and atmosphere build up. You go around, read some notes, explore a unique and beautiful looking environment. All is good, until you meet them. Until you hear them. Oh God.

The enemies in this game are incredibly grotesque, and I absolutely love it. Their gargling voices, and the things they say makes you feel so uneasy. You can't fight back. You just try to avoid them stealthily, or run away if they've noticed you.
The game makes you scared, without any lame tactics like overdone gore, or jumpscares.

Lastly, the music is fantastic.

I love everything about this world, and I think you should give it a try.

reviewText:
A sublime mix of influences seeming to comprise Pink Floyd, Guillermo Del Toro and Terry Gillian, Albino Lullaby:Episode 1 manages to stand out among the plethora of recent horror games by it's atmosphere alone.  Creepy and claustrophobic in some places and nightmarish and adrenaline pumped in others.
The graphics seem a little basic and underwhelming at first, until you start to get into the game and the realization hits that you no longer see them as a negative, but they fit the atmosphere perfectly.
The sound and music are absolutely spot-on.  The music plinks and plonks spookily in the background but swells to fever-pitch when you get spotted.  The voice acting is probably some of the best and worst I've seen in recent years, you can tell the voice actors put their all into the work.  The problem is that, again, it all fits together perfectly, both the good and the bad.
The gameplay is probably the hardest to review as the game seems to change it up from time to time, first it's an exploration game as you look around to try to find out who? what? where? and why?  Then it turns into a stealth
game, then it's a chase game as you run away from the enemies, then it's a puzzle game, then all combined.
All in all, yet again, it fits together well.

I would say if you enjoy horror games, or just fancy something a little different give it a try.
Grandmother would be very dissapointed in if you don't...

reviewText:
Albino Lullaby or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Laugh at the Giant Tim Curry Heads

Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

So it's that time of year again: Rosh Hashanah is upon us! Also, Halloween is right around the corner – and the upcoming flurry of spooky titles is reflective of that: SOMA, SKYHILL, and NBA 2K16 to name just a few. Leading the pack is one Albino Lullaby, an indie title from developer Ape Law who boldly claims their horror game doesn't rely on jumpscares, blood, or gore! Pretty exciting stuff... if they can deliver.

But unlike the ape-men in 2001: A Space Odyssey, Albino Lullaby regrettably just sort of stares quizzically at the monolith that is HORROR and promptly returns to throwing monkey spunk at one another until the heat death of the universe, never realizing their true potential. What could have been a terrifying, unique experience ends up looking like a half-baked horror walking sim with an (admittedly) lovely palette.

In Albino Lullaby you're just some guy having a midnight drive when you have an entirely avoidable accident. You awaken to find yourself in an otherworldly sort of prison that appears to be seemingly empty – ironically the best sort of prison situation to be in! It's at this point the game reaches peak spookiness for better or worse. I walked around slowly, checking every corner, waiting for the other shoe to drop. When that shoe finally does drop I was pursued by the suddenly ubiquitous Grandchildren (Giant Tim Curry Heads). While initially frightening the novelty wears off quickly after you're inevitably cornered. The Grandchildren just sort of menacingly gawk at you, sliding slowly towards you as your screen fades to black (it fades quicker in the proximity of multiple Grandchildren). First time I was cornered I just, well, laughed. After being “captured” the Grandchildren are toothless and slow; more comical than sinister (e.g., Tim Curry).

As you explore the strange carnival funhouse that is the primary environment of Albino Lullaby you'll find bizarre notes that kind-of-sort-of elaborate on the weird story behind the Grandchildren. It really isn't all that special (blah blah blah they're turning us into Tim Curry heads blah blah bizarre punishment/torture blah blah) and there's so damn many of them you'll eventually tire of collecting them and just push towards the unsatisfying end that felt longer to get to than the paltry two hours it actually took (M. Night Shyamalan levels of lame predictability - groan). It wasn't compelling, just nonsensical. That's pretty much the extent of the narrative.

Gameplay is fairly sparse. The primary element amounts to searching for keys or pressing a series of buttons hidden throughout a level. There's also, like, a “weapon” you get in the late game and a stupid containment puzzle and plugging in cords... what little gameplay there is feels tacked on simply to avoid the dreaded walking sim" denouncement - but that doesn't stop Albino Lullaby from being just that.

It isn't very good I'm afraid. Furthermore

reviewText:
Summary:

* Atmospheric Victorian steampunk environment with a suitably grotesque story
* A darkly cartoonish nightmare that's about rich imagery rather than scaring you silly
* Sometimes slow and puzzly, other times fast and forcing you to think on your feet.
* Creepiness is diluted by the time you get to the more action-driven later scenes
* Roughly 5 hours playthrough, with optional notes to collect
* Episode 2 is currently promised for Q2 2016

Full review:

Horror-wise, it's true that Albino Lullaby doesn't rely on jump scares or gore, although it does give you one or two sudden shocks and some unsettling grotesque imagery. It's more a forboding, dreamlike feeling, and use of dark surreal imagery that taps RIGHT into your dreams. It's paced nicely, with longer, slower bits building up dread, then the short release of a panicked chase or plummeting through madness.

The game is split loosely into a series of scenes, each letting you explore an area until you work out the puzzle/objective. Often it's just a case of finding the key or pressing enough buttons, but it mixes this up with mild stealth sections, panic-chases, rooftop navigation puzzles, arena fights and a clever action-puzzle towards the end where you need to work out how to trap somebody.

Gameplay highlights video of the first section:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W1S6mNxdBMQ

The core story is best experienced free of spoilers - the creepy evil worms you see on the advertising are obviously a major part of it, and beyond that it's all about slowly revealing the horrifying truth of who they are and who you are, all the time with the threat of a sinister Grandmother hanging over it all. The story happens through action (and figuring stuff out yourself) rather than cut scenes, although occasionally it'll freeze you to the spot so you can only look around while something crucial happens.

It looks beautiful and is lit brilliantly. Every scene sets a consistent mood of suffocating Victorian creepiness, with a dash of Steampunk and a dark hand-drawn cartoon aesthetic. Most locations are packed with little details that you can easily miss if you're in a rush - such as one of the evil worms taking a bath, or gravestones whose text reveals on inspection some disturbingly young deaths.

Similar detail is found on the now-traditional horror-game notes you can pick up. As usual they flesh out the story and provide atmosphere (or just jokes), while sometimes offering clues about stuff such as how the worms are afraid of something, suggesting that maybe you could use that to your advantage. You'll probably not miss much by ignoring them, though.

The game is never unfair, always making sure to teach you stuff before you have to rely on that knowledge during more dangerous situations (eg letting you work out how to fix a broken power line at your own pace before making you do it later in a panic).

As the story goes on, you get used to the initially creepy worms and by the time you have a weapon late in the game, you'll see them as cartoonish fodder. It's definitely less spooky and more plain surreal later on - at one point you're surrounded by broken clocks, toilets and furniture, and the on-screen mission objective literally becomes I dunno

Albino Lullaby is an interesting title. It's a first person horror game adventure, that promises no jump scares! That's great for people like me, who enjoy horror games, but not the jump scares.

Mechanically Albino Lullaby is a pretty simple game. Walk around taking in the sights, collecting notes, and try not to get creeped out too much. Later on the game will introduce some minor stealth and combat mechanics as well. The game is really a lot more about the experience of it's atmosphere and story much more than it's mechanics.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iWumjp91t-Y
The game's visuals is probably one the high points for Albino Lullaby. The textures have this pencil sketch look to it, the environments and characters are both beautiful and creepy at the same time. The game utilizes Unreal 4's engine for some pretty impressive lighting and rendering. The visuals are complimented by it's audio, with creepy background noises, subtle musical cues, and impressive voice acting. The game's presentation is spot on with what it's trying to achieve.

Though I certainly enjoyed the game greatly, it's not with out it's faults. My number one compliant has to be it's performance. Though the beginning half of the game runs relatively well with above 60FPS consistently, the second half is mired with tons of frame drops. reviewText:
Introduction.
When the scariest part of a horror game is the framerate, you know you’re in trouble.

Albino Lullaby: Episode One is a ‘horror’ game set in a strange mansion filled with what the game calls Grandchildren. Neither knowing how you’ve ended up in this strange place nor what it is, you have to navigate through the mansion in order to find a way out. At least that’s what I think is going on, it doesn’t really explain it. I don’t want to dedicate an entire paragraph to a non-existent story so I’ll just go ahead and say that the ending is disappointing to say the least.

Presentation.
Albino Lullaby has an interesting art style, somewhere between cel-shaded and realistic. However, this art style is rarely visible in anything other than the game world itself, the Grandchildren aren’t of this style and neither are the notes, keys, ghost shadow things etc. On top of inconsistency, many of the textures are low quality, particularly the larger ones, as they end up looking like they’ve just been stretched. There’s not really any user interface in the game, apart from the occasional tooltip, but there’s not really any need for one. Visual effects are also lacking, in particular the fire and the clouds of debris coming off of crushed objects.


Gameplay.
Albino Lullaby is, effectively, a walking simulator set in a really odd house. You’re given no direction in the game so you have to figure out everything for yourself, I’ll let you decide whether or not that’s something you like. When you do figure out what to do, it’s almost always: go find x number of buttons, press them and then come back here to press this other button that’ll let open something so you can progress. If it isn’t that, you’re just walking around trying to find your way to the next place with buttons. Now, this could be somewhat interesting if you were absolutely bricking it while playing the game but as you may have guessed from my intro, this game isn’t even slightly scary. Why isn’t it scary you ask? It’s a combination of three things. First off, the game isn’t atmospheric at all, audio isn’t used very well and the contrast of light and dark isn’t used well either, it’s generally either really bright or really dark. Next, we have the fact that the Grandchildren, the only ‘threat’ to you, are not even slightly scary, if anything they’re amusing due to their resemblance to the male genitalia. Lastly, we have the fact that our only ‘threat’ pose absolutely no threat to you. Early on in the game it’s remarkably easy to just walk past them with no consequence and later on in the game you get a tool which helps you, shall we say, get rid of danger with ease.

Performance.
Now for the most part, the game run okay-ish. I managed to maintain 30FPS with maxed out settings with a few minor framerate drops every so often. However, when you get to the last part of the game, performance takes a hit, a really big hit and things get rough. At this point in the game you’ll be luck to scrape 15FPS running on minimum graphics setting across the board and as you can imagine, trying to play a game at 15FPS is not fun. Albino Lullaby is also riddled with bugs and glitches. I regularly encountered bugs where I would just end up walking through walls and into the maps as well as lots of graphical glitches such as texture flickering when turning. Most notably, I have a game-breaking bug which actually prevents me from completing the game myself so I’ve relied upon friends to tell me the bitterly disappointing ending.

Audio.
As I mentioned, the audio in Albino Lullaby does nothing to create a scary or even slightly creepy atmosphere. In a lot of horror games that I’ve played, the sound effects themselves (when timed correctly of course) are terrifying, even just basic, everyday noises. Albino Lullaby fails on this front, the sound effects seem to just be randomly played now and again and had no real effect on me. Unfortunately the voice acting isn’t much better. Now, don’t get me wrong, the voice actors are actually pretty good, the reason the voice acting is overall lacking is due to the fact the voice acting doesn’t fit the game. It’s so over the top that you’d expect it to be in a more humorous game, perhaps this was meant to be a humorous game (?) but instead it just feels out of place.

Verdict.
Not Worth Purchasing Unless Heavily Discounted.

Albino Lullaby is a nice idea, horror without gore, jump scares and blood. Perhaps it could have pulled it off if the game had a scary atmosphere, but it doesn’t, and so Albino Lullaby is just a walking simulator with some buttons to press and some Grandkids to run away from. Hopefully the devs will learn from episode one and the second of three will be better but I’m not going to hold my breath.

reviewText:
I made a video review of this game. There's a lot to love, but there's definetely hiccups

Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VmRzAYGQ-z8

Transcript:

When I began Albino Lullaby, I was completely captivated; by the art style, by the music everything. I was interested in the world that was being presented to me, and, honestly, for the first 5 - 10 minutes it doesn’t feel that much like a horror game. As the game continues on I started to feel the creepiness coming through, with clever little details around in the world that really make you uneasy. So, as I approached the end of the game, I began to wonder “What went wrong?”

Ape Law sold this game as horror without cheap jump-scares; they promised fear, but that fear would be built through the world and the atmosphere, rather than exploiting that surprise reflex that the horror genre really likes to ♥♥♥♥ with.

And, for the most part, they accomplish this, though after a while it stopped being all that scary for me. The atmosphere was awesome all the way throughout, but from about the half-way point I was playing pretty recklessly -- I didn’t feel the need to hide or sneak my way past any of the monsters; because they aren’t all that hard to avoid, though I recognize that might not be the point.

Like I said, the best part of the game is about the first half. And, unfortunately, that’s only about 1-2 hours in. The game isn’t very long -- it’s supposed to be the first part of an episodic trilogy, which is, as we’ve seen with Telltale, a perfectly viable business model. But, this episode took me about 3-4 hours to complete; not much longer than a Telltale episode, but it’s double the price. As far as I’m aware, a single Telltale episode goes for around $5. This game is $10, and it’s season pass is $25. That’s a pretty premium price.

I also feel the gameplay was padded out with some tedious sections, and the checkpoints are very sparse. Now, this wouldn’t be a problem if the game required any skill, but it’s basically trial and error. Trial and error with barely any checkpoints leads to a pretty frustrating experience a lot of the time. In particular, one section with an elevator. You need to survive here for a couple of minutes with the main enemies of the game, but the checkpoint takes you to a spot way before you even reach the elevator. It doesn’t help that it’s easy to die, and simply not knowing what you have to do means you have to start over a lot.

The reason that particular section sticks out for me, is because up until that point the framerate was fine. But in this section with the elevator (and for even longer than that, this goes on for maybe 30 minutes) the average frame-rate was at 20. At one point I say it go down to 7 frames per second. I’m not sure if they just didn’t have time, because up until that point the performance was ok. It would sometimes drop to 50ish frames but that was the worst of it. This section of the game becomes nearly unplayable, and I even tested it on lower settings and with recording turned off; no dice.

Unfortunately, I’d have to say wait for a sale unless you are REALLY into story-driven horror games that have an impressive and creative world. It’s a real shame because, like I said, there’s a lot to love in this game, and there is clearly talent behind it. I am excited for the next part, which is slated for quarter 2 of 2016 I think it said at the end, because I want to see where the story goes. I liked the ending to this episode, and I liked all of the crazy world building details throughout the mechanical mansion. And I haven’t even mentioned how they managed to strike this bizarrely effective balance, between the monsters being comedic, and them being terrifying at the same time.

The game is absolutely worth a look. But it’s gotta be on sale, or you have to be a massive fan of the atmosphere for it to be worth it.

Thanks for watching,

See ya!

Beetlejuice era Tim Burton walks into a bar with Henry Selick, they get drunk, have a nice night together and when they wake up they’ve birthed this wonderful game. Also, Psychonauts Tim Schafer is the GodFather.

This is the first episode of a series of titles all under the Albino Lullaby name from Ape Law Studios with the second coming next year. I don’t know if I can wait that long.

A. There was an accident

In fact a large part of this game is based around accidents. I spent about 2 hours stumbling around, trying to not die, again.

Screw you game, you don’t know my life.

I wish I could write more about this title, but normally I don’t touch episodics until they are a few episodes in, or completed. Looking at you Kentucky Route Zero. What I can say is that for 9.99 this title provided me with around 3 hours of fun and ‘WTF’ moments. I found myself pulled in by the setting, challenged by the levels and from each death educated on what not to do, or where to stand.


There were moments of frustration, until I stopped and looked around. There’s some backtracking, and key finding. Also some plugging stuff in and doing things and other stuff.

There is one point in particular where I’m not sure if I broke the game, or if it’s what I was supposed to do. Regardless, it worked and carried me forward, towards it’s conclusion. Though, since this is an episodic game I don’t feel that conclusion should be used here. It’s break until the next chapter.

The game makes you laugh while remaining creepy and giving you a sense of unease. No jump scares here, it’s all in your head.

With this title please place your seats into the upright position, attach your headphones firmly to your ears and turn the lights down low. It’s going to be a trippy ride.

Review
Albino lullaby is an exploration based horror game by Ape Law, in it you play an unnamed character who wakes up in a strange mechanical house and must explore to find out why you're there and what brought you there.

Pros     Grapics, are beautiful and interesting, with a style reminiscent of crayon colouring books.
The music is beautiful, at times haunting.
The atmosphere created in this game through the clever use of music and sounds is very creepy and gives a feeling of emptyness throughout gameplay.
The backstory is interesting and very discomforting, the way the story is given through the use of scattered notes as well as environmentally (such as the dentist chair seen in the screenshots above) is very intuitive and to some degree allows players to choose how much story they want to ingest.
Gameplay is simple, the game is easy to pick up and play (double edged sword, see cons.)
No jumpscares! They decided to not take the lazy way out when scaring players.
The weird head things are pretty neat.
Cons     Found the game to lag quite a bit after the first play area. (I have a GTX 970 and I7 for reference)
Had issues with recording the game in some areas.
Gameplay is rather simple, meaning some players may easily become bored if they don't enjoy exploring.
When I first played I thought my character was a baby because of a glitch (can be seen in video), also couldn't run.
The game seems to crash if you tab out on the opening cutscene (not a huge issue, just don't tab out until you reach the start menu.)
Conclusion
This game is very well done in terms of fear factor and atmosphere, the music is beautiful and creepy which adds to the atmosphere of the game as well as giving the player something interesting to listen to. While the gameplay mechanics and puzzles are rather simple, I personally enjoyed the exploration aspect of the game enough that it didn't get boring to play. No jumpscares! not much more needs to be said about that. The story is discomforting and, at times, made me stop playing briefly to digest it, which is how a horror game should be.

For content creators, this game can be quite buggy and I found it lagged substantially during recording, so unless you really want to record this game, maybe think about recording a different series.

6/10 If you enjoy exploring worlds with a good backstory.
5/10 otherwise.

reviewText:
Note: I did not play this in VR.

The intro was really...weird.  There wasn't really an explanation, just 'Here's a random guy who is now driving a car, sees a ghost in the road and drives to the other lane, aaaanndd dead.'  Introductions are arguably the most important aspect when jumping into a game like this.  You really need to know what the story/backgound is to understand the game.  It'd be nice had there been a bit more explanation.

For whatever reason alt-tabbing is not a thing.  When I tried, the game acted like I had alt-tabbed, as the music stopped, but the game remained on my screen, and I couldn't click within it.  It appears that when you try and alt-tab,  you do technically alt-tab out of the game, but the game fails to minimize.  Alt-tabbing is something everyone does on all games, so it baffles me why developers make it so that the game has to stay on your screen the entire time it's open.

The game sounds were really well put together.  I'm normally not a huge fan of music in games, whether it be eery music or actual songs, but in AL it's actually very enjoyable to listen to.  You also seem to always be on edge due to the sounds, which fits this game perfectly.

Indie horror games usually aren't as good as you'd hope.  They'd either lack actual fright, or the story would just be terribly done.  AL has done horror right.  As I previously said, when you walk around in game you're on edge, and you're wondering what is coming.

There is controller support, which I found it better to use a controller.  You can still play it perfectly well with keyboard and mouse, but if you have a controller, I advise using it.  It was just easier for me.


Positives:

Can be played in VR.

Controller support.

Good music/general game sounds.

One of the better horror games.
Negatives:

Can't alt-tab.

Poorly done intro.

Now, this is a neat game. However, that does not mean it did not come with its share of annoyances.
NOTE: This is not a full review. So, before you pull your panties up to your chin and blow steam in my face; This is simply me quickly noting how I feel about the game with the time I have played. Pros:
1) Atmospheric: Semi-unique, unlike most lackluster 'horror' games out there. For some reason every single horror game developer seems to think that making the game as grim as America's future would suffice in creating atmosphere ... it is not. It's nice to see that there are still developers out there that are willing to stand out in a market dominated by mediocrity.
2) Interesting Monsters (Grandchildren): They look and sound funny, yet eerie, which does suit the sinister tone that the game sets from the start. Too bad there's so b@stardly many of them, which removes the tension when coming across one.
3) Performance: Who cares. Is alright. I can appreciate Style over Insane Graphics.
4) Next to no jumpscares. The game was advertised as a horror game completely without jumpscares, which is unfortunately not entirely true. I suppose it depends on how you interpret the term 'jumpscare.' It is certainly nice to not have developers throw cheap jumpscare after jumpscare in your face, like we are used to with Until Dawn, Layers of Fear, Outlast, and all those other horrendous wannabe horror games.

Cons:
1) Story sets off oddly vague. I'm not sure if there is supposed to be a story line here ... if so I completely missed it, despite reading pretty much every single one of the notes.
2) Press a couple of buttons on walls, die, repeat. There's 'puzzles' which consist of you running around, pressing buttons on walls, whilst avoiding the absolutely butt♥♥♥♥fest around you. The Grandchildren spawn rate is a bit rediculous. It does not take long for them to swarm most of the map. Not to mention floors disappearing, leaving you falling into Oblivion and dying, and ceiling dropping on your head, killing you instantly. ''Try Harder Next Time.'' .... Try Polishing Your Game Next Time. It's just insulting.
3) Missed opportunity after the beginning section. Instead of being the trippy, mind♥♥♥♥y horror game that it is advertised to be, you will mostly find yourself running around the map not knowing what you're doing or where you should be looking for objectives. reviewText:
In it's current state I don't believe Albino Lullaby is fit for sale. What I experienced was a buggy mess with gameplay that barely functioned correctly and a horror element that wasn't scary.

Before I go into what made me hate the game so much I will briefly talk about the few thing I did like about the game. The first of them is the graphics style. I love the cartoony style that the characters and world are animated in. It's simple but very effective. The world is full of colour.

Added into this is just purely the setting of the world. The basics of the setting is a mechanical household world with rooms that can move about by the press of buttons. Parts of the world seem to be a kind of mad house setting. The outdoors sections of the world are beautiful colourful settings. The world is set upon a seemingly endless pit. The setting of the world really got my attention.

I was also rather fond of the story. Fitting into this uniquely designed world is also a very unique story. It seems to be that there is a cult following from grandchildren to what they call the grandmother. You find out some very creepy facts around the world. The majority of the story is told through notes found around the world. Unfortunately the story has a cliffhanger ending at the moment due to it being episodic though.

Unfortunately this is about as far as my good experiences went for the game. I guess I'll probably start with explaining what I didn't like about the horror, since thats probably why your looking at this game in the first place. The game seems to pride itself on not using jump scares. This means they have limited options on how to carry out horror. They needed to create a horrifying atmosphere instead. Unfortunately they didn't do this. There only attempt at horror was the enemies (called the grandchildren). They're creepy for about the first minute you see them and then they just get to be neusance. The way they focus on the horror in these enemies are through the voices. They have a kind of creepy tone to them. This creeped me out when I first saw them and then just got annoying.

Which brings me nicely into my next point. The voice acting. I mean it's kind of a mixed bag. I enjoyed the enemies voices at first. There voices were usually in a kinda high pitched old man kinda tone. But this gets old quickly and very annoying. And then you realize the voice acting isn't actually good at all. The other issue with this is that the enemies repeat the same quotes multiple times. There isn't enough variety in what they say to last through the game.

The biggest issue I had throughout play was a game breaking bug. Through fault of the game I had managed to go backwards an objective through a door opening when it shouldn't have. This made me had to complete this section again. However I couldn't. When I got to a door that I had went through before when completing the objective it was seemingly blocked by a rock. This meant there was no way for me to continue to progress. It meant I had to completely restart the entire game from the beginning again. I was about 1.5 hours into the game so I wasn't particularly happy about this. I attempted to speed run the game again to the point I was up to which took me about an extra half hour of gameplay still. I reached out to the developer about this issue and they are looking into it. Whats worse is it isn't the only game breaking bug out there. A friend of mine also experienced one that had an inmovable enemy blocking his way.

Another buggy part of the game is the way stealth mechanics work. To be honest they don't really work at all. Sometimes enemies seem to spot you when your nowhere near in sight to them and other times they don't spot you when your right in front of them. This means you have to be extra careful to try and make sure the game doesn't mess it up for you. But whats even worse is when you do get spotted. There is seemingly no way to escape them. Hiding out for a while doesn't make them loose attention for you. Every enemy in the world seems to locked to pathing towards you whether they have any kind of vision on you or not. Stealth missions really aren't fun to do because of this.

Then combat isn't much better either. Later in the game you get this device called the clicker. When you use it it creates a green orb in front of you. All enemies in this orb at the time get knocked out for a while. The problem with this is that the orb makes is so you can't see were your going. It is exceedingly bright and large so much so it covers basically all of your visiblity.

Talking about visibility you don't really have much of that throughout the world either. The game is way too dark in a lot of areas. It's so dark that at various points throughout the game I found myself having to guess where I could actually go. So therefore a lot of the time I also found myself walking off of the world accidently. The settings has no option for brightness so I couldn't fix this. The only option there is was for the detail of the shadows which seemed to make no difference.

Performance is also terrible on Albino Lullaby. I have a system that should easily be capable of playing through this game at a constant 60fps. However I barely managed to get 40fps throughout most of the game and had frequent framerate drops to unplayable levels. At one point in the game it dropped to an abismal 5fps and stayed like that. I had to change all my settings to the lowest and still only got about 20fps. It is unacceptable to have a game this poorly optimized!

Another small complaint is with the notes. When I am being chased by enemies I don't want to be having to read notes. If I do have to then I would like the game to pause for me to read it. I found myself having to rush my reading so I don't get killed by an enemy while doing it.

On top of all this issues I had other smaller bugs with clipping, getting stuck in the world, jumpiness in elevators and bad parkour mechanics. I also completed the game in probably about between 2-3 hours so it's not long of a length.

At the state this game is in at the moment I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. The developers really need to try and fix a lot of these issues and make the game just overall more fun in general. I really think the game has a lot of potential with the setting and story drawing it forward but it's not living up to it. It may be worth picking up in a few months time after a load of patches but for now I don't think it is.

Okay, this review has previously been negative and I'll have to change that now. There was a small collection of reasons that made me believe that Albino Lullaby on Steam doesn't actually have proper Oculus Rift support but instead hooks up to Steam VR. (Which, for games that do it this way, somewhat works but usually leads to a suboptimal performance / experience.)

When launching the game the following happens:

- When starting Albion Lullaby you have to pick the option to launch it in Steam VR. (otherwise it will be pure 2D)
- At first Steam VR starts, but when launching the game in VR afterwards (and this is what I didn't notice) Steam VR isn't actually used, but Albino Lullaby hooks up to the Oculus Rift runtime directly. (version 1.3 at the time of this review)

This behaviour combined with the fact that the runtime 1.3 version of this game wasn't available at the time of the launch on Steam (but on the Oculus Home Store) led me to believe that 'proper' Rift support was only available in the version of the Oculus Home Store, which made me quite angry. ;)

Also note the following before reading my review:
I have a bit of offline playtime, but I haven't finished the game yet.
I'm playing on the Oculus Rift DK2 using runtime 1.3.

------

Now that this is out of the way I can get back to the game:

The game is actually really nice. The environments are extremely surreal and the atmosphere is built up quite effectively. IMHO this is one of the horror games owners of VR headsets really should get! One specialty of Albino Lullaby is, that it doesn't rely on jumpscares. Others have stated that the game is 'not scary', but I suppose that depends on how one defines the term 'scary' ... depending on what one considers to be scary the statement might be true, but then again: Scaring someone, at least in my opinion, isn't really the objective of this game for the most part. It does build what I'd call a cocktail of certain other feelings like anxiety"

reviewText:
Although the art style, setting and attention to detail is there I beg the question why is this in VR? I was hoping for some novel motion solution but no, the experience is using a standard first person controller which you control either by a mouse or controller. The constant turning eventually made me feel quite sick and I just had to put the experience down.

Other aspects of the game have simply NOT been thought through for VR; you constantly pick up obscurely written notes, but they appear so close to your eyes with the lense distortion on the Oculus/HTC at the peripheral of the lense you cant make out the first couple of sentences.

Virtual Reality is all about depth & spatial perception. Which means flat textures that you can get away with in a standard FPS do not work in VR. Things like door handles were not modelled onto doors, but simply on the texture.

In conclusion although visually very rich and obviously with a lot of character this is NOT a VR game. At best its a first person puzzle game injected into VR.

Easily feel sick? Stay clear!!

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cPcZAQzRQTw

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

If you play this game with the expectation of an horror experience, you will be disappointed, and I will not recommend it as a horror game. The surreal element and excellent voice acting may make this enjoyable for those that enjoy a bizarre walking simulator through.

Albino Lullaby proclaims itself to be an adventure horror game with no jump scares or gore.  You are transported by who knows what means to a surreal world that you are attempting to escape from while avoiding bizarre monsters. The game offers little notes to explain more fully about your surroundings and answer some questions, but the combination of the notes end up not really explaining too much, and the save points being so far spread out gives the player little incentive to seek out and find them all. The story overall is confusing, and the atmosphere of the game can best be described as the product of a carnival haunted house, and the Rocky Horror Picture show. It doesn't make all that much sense, just attempt to navigate the odd environment. The voice acting of the monsters is very well done, and adds an interesting element of intrigue to the game.

The scale and detail of the levels really shows that a lot of creativity, effort and love has gone into it. It is unique in it's design, where even when you have to go back to previously explored areas,those areas have changed just enough to make it seem like an all new experience.

The game relies on stealth to maintain a sense of horror, and the players ability to remain excited and engaged in avoiding getting caught by monsters. In this aspect, I feel the game falls short. The monsters, while at the start of the game may be spooky and frightening, do not change as you play the game, and do not carry the weight needed to keep that sense of horror. Its more so becomes an intense game of tag, as when one monster notices you, all on that level do, and you spend your time trying to dodge them not hide.To make it worse, even if you are able to manipulate the environment to kill them, they respawn, so you never feel as if you have cleared an area completely. In a stealth game, one relies on sneaking in shadows to avoid being seen, but the lighting is such that even if you think you are in complete darkness, in a pitch black corner, the monsters can still see you.  Then you end up just trying to run through the level, as once you are seen, as I have said, you are seen by all. No light gem or floor sounds that differ on the types of floors you walk on makes you always unsure if the monster will or will not see you.

I would describe this game more as spooky than horror. The game does feel a bit drawn out because of the distance between checkpoints, meaning if you fail its a long way to back track. I didn't feel drawn to the character, or particularly motivated to do what the game wants me to. There may be answers in further episodes to the slew of unanswered ones here, but as it stands right now, I didn't feel a sense of intrigue or desire to know what happens.

Disclosure: I'm a tertiary dev of this game for some of the writing, but the main story and development (including any documentation or playthroughs pre-release (besides demos released to the public)) were not known to me before my main play through of the released build.

Art: Yes. Gameplay: Indie-core Audio: Absolutely.  Story: Welcome home.

This is a game for someone who isn't looking for another AAA horror experience. This is a triple I kind of game, many of the devs ex-AAA themselves though. The game's designs and methods actually pay several homages to different devs, if you know what you're looking for. But priorities of the game are essentially indie: quality in music, story, art. Gameplay is not an after thought, and some creative things are done with it, but you might want to call this more of an adventure game before you call it a puzzle game or a survival game (though there are hints of those). The main activities you are doing often have to do with keeping any sort of coherency. It is a weird and confusing and fun and creepy experience.

Play this game if you like story first games. If you want to be creeped out and if you're willing to invest in a deep scare. Episode one ends on a high note where things promise to go from somewhat scary to deeply disturbing. It's an honest and impressive show for a small indie's first release. It comes with some bugs and so forth, but with the boost of sales a successful release (here's hoping), the sequels promise to be even better than what the first episode delivers, as they'll have the capitol to insure even greater production quality. It's an exciting and creepy little seed, which I expect will grow into a beautiful monstrosity in the near future.
